title: Valleylab Force FX ESU – Return Electrode (Pad) Alarm / Won’t Enable Cut or Coag
description: Troubleshooting guide for Valleylab Force FX ESU return electrode alarms preventing Cut or Coag activation, focusing on external causes before internal REM circuit failure.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: Do not troubleshoot while the ESU is connected to an active patient. Confirm the patient has been transitioned to another ESU if surgery is ongoing. Verify the generator is in standby mode before making adjustments. This prevents unintended activation and protects the patient.

steps.title: Verify Return Electrode Is Properly Applied
steps.instructions: Confirm the pad is fully adhered to clean, dry, hair-free skin. Check for partial lifting, wrinkles, or air pockets. Ensure correct pad placement over a large, well-vascularized muscle mass. Poor pad contact is the most common cause of REM alarms. If the pad appears compromised, replace it with a new one.

steps.title: Confirm Correct Pad Type
steps.instructions: Verify that a split (REM-compatible) return electrode is being used. Ensure it is compatible with the Valleylab Force FX REM system. Using a solid (non-split) pad or incompatible pad will trigger alarms and prevent activation.

steps.title: Inspect the Return Electrode Cable
steps.instructions: Check for bent pins, loose connectors, or damaged insulation. Ensure the connector is fully seated in the return electrode port. Wiggle the connector gently to see if the alarm clears or intermittently changes. If damage is noted, replace the cable and retest.

steps.title: Swap with a Known-Good Cable
steps.instructions: Disconnect the current return electrode cable. Connect a known-good cable. Attach to a new pad (not the existing one). If the alarm clears, the issue was likely cable-related.

steps.title: Check for Fluid Contamination
steps.instructions: Inspect the return electrode port for saline, prep solution, or debris. Ensure the connector is dry and free of contamination. Moisture can interfere with REM sensing and cause persistent alarms.

steps.title: Power Cycle the Unit
steps.instructions: Turn the unit off. Wait 30–60 seconds. Restart and observe whether the alarm persists. Transient REM circuit faults may clear with a reset.

steps.title: Perform Functional Test (Without Patient)
steps.instructions: Using a test pad or simulator (if available), connect the return electrode. Verify the REM indicator shows normal status. Attempt activation into an ESU analyzer. If the alarm persists with known-good accessories and no patient involved, the issue is likely internal.

CCR.Complaint: OR staff reported return electrode alarm on Valleylab Force FX. Unit would not enable Cut or Coag during setup.
CCR.Cause: Return electrode cable found to have intermittent connection at generator plug. Alarm triggered when cable was manipulated.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced return electrode cable with known-good cable. Verified REM normal indication and successful activation into ESU analyzer. Returned unit to service.

title: Valleylab Force FX Electrosurgical Unit – No Output or Weak Output
description: Troubleshooting guide for Valleylab Force FX ESU producing no or weak output in Cut or Coag modes, focusing on external causes before internal failure.

steps.title: Ensure Patient Safety First
steps.instructions: Confirm the ESU is not connected to an active patient. If output is in question during a case, have clinical staff transition to a backup generator immediately before troubleshooting. This prevents unintended injury or surgical delay.

steps.title: Verify Power to the Unit
steps.instructions: Confirm the unit is plugged into a known-good outlet. Check for proper power-on indicators. If connected to a power strip or boom outlet, verify that the outlet is energized. Why this matters: Inconsistent power can allow the unit to power on but not deliver proper output under load.

steps.title: Confirm Output Mode and Settings
steps.instructions: Verify correct mode (Cut, Coag, Blend). Confirm wattage setting is appropriate for the intended procedure. Ensure the unit is not in a standby or default low-power setting. Incorrect settings can mimic weak output.

steps.title: Inspect the Active Electrode Pencil
steps.instructions: Check the handpiece for damage or contamination. Ensure the electrode tip is fully seated. Replace the pencil with a known-good pencil if available. Damaged or high-resistance handpieces commonly cause weak output.

steps.title: Check the Footswitch (If Applicable)
steps.instructions: Verify the footswitch cable is fully seated. Test both pedals (Cut and Coag). Try activating using the hand control pencil if available. A failed footswitch or broken cable can prevent output even when the unit appears normal.

steps.title: Inspect the Patient Return Electrode (Grounding Pad)
steps.instructions: Confirm proper placement and full adhesion. Check that the return electrode cable is fully inserted. Inspect for pad drying, lifting edges, or expired packaging. Try a new return electrode if unsure. Poor return contact increases impedance and may reduce or prevent output.

steps.title: Check for REM (Return Electrode Monitoring) Alarms
steps.instructions: Look for REM alarm indicators or error messages. Confirm the correct pad type (split vs. solid) is being used. REM detection may disable output if improper pad connection is detected.

steps.title: Inspect Output Receptacles
steps.instructions: Ensure the active output port is secure. Check for bent pins or visible damage. Confirm the correct output port is being used. Connection issues at the generator output port can reduce energy delivery.

steps.title: Swap Accessories Systematically
steps.instructions: Replace the active electrode. Replace the return electrode and cable. Replace the footswitch. Try another known-good ESU on the same accessories (if available). Systematic isolation prevents unnecessary generator removal.

steps.title: Check for Error Codes or Self-Test Failures
steps.instructions: Power cycle the unit. Observe startup self-test. Document any displayed error codes. Failure during internal diagnostics suggests internal generator issues.

CCR.Complaint: OR reports no cut effect during procedure despite activation.
CCR.Cause: High-resistance active electrode pencil identified; output normal after accessory swap.
CCR.Resolution: Replaced active electrode pencil. Verified proper output in Cut and Coag modes using ESU analyzer. Returned unit to service.

helpfulDetails: Final device status (Returned to service / Sent to vendor)

title: Valleylab Force FX ESU – Error Codes / Self-Test Failure at Power-Up
description: Troubleshooting guide for Valleylab Force FX ESU self-test failures and startup error codes, focusing on external power and accessory checks before escalation.

steps.title: Ensure the Unit Is Not Connected to a Patient
steps.instructions: If connected to an active case, immediately transfer the patient to a backup ESU before troubleshooting. Do not power-cycle repeatedly during an active surgical procedure.

steps.title: Perform a Full Power Reset
steps.instructions: Turn the unit OFF. Disconnect the power cord from the wall outlet. Wait at least 60 seconds. Reconnect directly to a known-good wall outlet (not a power strip). Power ON and observe the startup sequence. Why this matters: Temporary logic faults or voltage instability can trigger self-test failures.

steps.title: Verify the Wall Outlet and Line Power
steps.instructions: Confirm the outlet is hospital-grade and functioning. Test outlet with an outlet tester or plug in another known-good device. Avoid extension cords or daisy-chained power strips. Power irregularities commonly trigger startup errors.

steps.title: Disconnect All Accessories
steps.instructions: Remove active electrode handpiece. Disconnect return electrode (REM) cable. Remove footswitch. Remove any adapters or extension cables. Power the unit ON with nothing connected. Why this matters: Faulty accessories can cause impedance or detection errors during self-test.

steps.title: Inspect the Return Electrode (REM) Port
steps.instructions: Check for bent pins. Check for debris or fluid contamination. Ensure no foreign objects are inside the port. REM detection failures are a common cause of startup errors.

steps.title: Check for Environmental or Fluid Exposure Issues
steps.instructions: Inspect for signs of fluid ingress. Look for corrosion around connectors. Note any unusual odor (burning smell). Check for excessive heat from the chassis. If fluid intrusion is suspected, stop troubleshooting and escalate.

steps.title: Document the Exact Error Code Displayed
steps.instructions: Record the exact code and message. Note whether the unit fails immediately or midway through self-test. Note any audible tones or alarm patterns. Precise documentation helps determine whether the issue is power supply–related, memory-related, or internal board-related.

steps.title: Attempt Startup on a Different Circuit (If Available)
steps.instructions: Move the unit to a separate, known-good circuit in another room if feasible. If the error clears, building power instability may be contributing.

CCR.Complaint: Unit displays error code during startup and will not enter ready mode.
CCR.Cause: Unit failed internal self-test at power-up. Error persisted after full power reset and accessory removal. No external power issues identified.
CCR.Resolution: Removed unit from service, labeled Out of Service, and sent to Biomed shop for further evaluation and repair.

helpfulDetails: Any unusual odor, sound, or heat
